verses.text: Then David came to Nob, to Ahimelech the priest. Ahimelech trembled when he met David, and said to him, 'Why are you alone, and no one with you?'
verses.comment: David comes to Nob, significant as a priestly city. His solitary arrival arouses suspicion, foreshadowing the trials of God's chosen. The priestly context hints at the sacred continuity of temple worship (see Lev. 21).

verses.text: David replied to Ahimelech, 'The king has sent me on a secret mission and said, ‘Let no one know anything about the matter I am sending you and instructing you in.’ I have directed my young men to such-and-such a place.'
verses.comment: David withholds the true reason for his journey, preserving both his life and the safety of the priest. The secrecy reflects the notion of divine wisdom that sometimes requires prudent concealment (cf. Matt. 10:16).

verses.text: 'Now then, what do you have on hand? Give me five loaves of bread, or whatever is here.'
verses.comment: David requests bread, linking this scene to Christ’s reference in Matthew 12:3-4, where Jesus acknowledges the precedence of mercy and necessity before ritual, pointing to a deeper fulfillment in Christ's own ministry.

verses.text: The priest answered David, 'There is no common bread on hand, but there is holy bread—if your men have kept themselves from women.'
verses.comment: The priest’s condition regarding the holy bread deepens our understanding of purity before God. This foreshadows how grace can make even the holy accessible in times of need, paralleling sacramental themes.

verses.text: David replied to the priest, 'Indeed, women have been kept from us as usual when I go on a mission. The vessels of the young men are holy, even if this trip is ordinary; how much more today will their vessels be holy?'
verses.comment: David affirms ritual purity among his men, showing respect for divine law. This emphasis on maintaining holiness echoes the principle of preparing oneself before encountering the sacred.

verses.text: So the priest gave him the holy bread, for there was no bread there except the bread of the Presence, which had been removed from before the Lord, to be replaced with hot bread on the day it was taken away.
verses.comment: Here David, though not a priest, partakes in a priestly privilege. Jesus later uses this event to show the precedence of mercy over legalism (Matt. 12:4), hinting at a higher fulfillment.

verses.text: Now one of Saul’s servants was there that day, detained before the Lord. His name was Doeg the Edomite, the chief of Saul’s shepherds.
verses.comment: Doeg’s presence sets up later betrayal. ‘Detained before the Lord’ may suggest ritual obligation or discipline, showing how even the unfaithful can be present in holy assemblies.

verses.text: David said to Ahimelech, 'Do you have a spear or sword here? I did not bring my sword or my weapons with me, because the king’s mission was urgent.'
verses.comment: David requests a weapon, stressed by urgency—possibly a practical reason but also serves to connect the storyline about trusting God's providence and past victories (like Goliath’s defeat).

verses.text: The priest said, 'The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you killed in the valley of Elah, is here. It is wrapped in a cloth behind the ephod. If you want to take it, take it, for there is no other here.' David replied, 'There is none like it; give it to me.'
verses.comment: David’s acceptance of Goliath’s sword emphasizes a tangible reminder of past deliverance, yet still taken from a priestly context, underscoring the divine favor in victory rather than human strength alone.

verses.text: Then David arose and fled that day from Saul, and went to Achish the king of Gath.
verses.comment: David seeks refuge among the Philistines, notably Goliath's hometown, illustrating the reversal of circumstance and the mystery of divine providence.

verses.text: The servants of Achish said to him, 'Is this not David the king of the land? Did they not sing of him to one another in dances, ‘Saul has slain his thousands, and David his tens of thousands?’'
verses.comment: David’s fame precedes him, and the Philistines acknowledge his kingship—foreshadowing his future anointing and the universal recognition of God's chosen, pointing ahead to Christ’s kingship.

verses.text: David took these words to heart and was very much afraid of Achish king of Gath.
verses.comment: David’s fear here is human and relatable, giving depth to his dependence on God. This moment inspires later reflection in the Psalms about fear and trust in God’s providence.

verses.text: So he pretended to be insane before them. He acted mad among them, making marks on the doors of the gate and letting saliva run down his beard.
verses.comment: David uses cleverness for survival. Tradition links this moment to the composition of Psalm 34, a hymn of thanksgiving to God for deliverance—reflecting the theme that divine protection can operate through humble means.

verses.text: Then Achish said to his servants, 'Look, you see the man is insane. Why bring him to me?'
verses.comment: Achish’s reaction spares David’s life. The providence here resonates with the protection of God’s chosen, comparable to moments when Christ Himself was delivered from peril due to the divine plan.

verses.text: 'Do I lack madmen, that you have brought this fellow to behave as a madman in my presence? Shall this man come into my house?'
verses.comment: Achish refuses David entry and thus David is spared—illustrating that sometimes God's will is accomplished through the seemingly foolish or unexpected, a recurring theme in Scripture (cf. 1 Cor. 1:27).
